event.descr:
An ospfTxRetransmit trap signifies than an OSPF packet has been retransmitted on a non- virtual interface. All packets that may be re- transmitted are associated with an LSDB entry. The LS type, LS ID, and Router ID are used to identify the LSDB entry.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfNbrRtrId %parm[#4]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#5]%; hello(1) dbDescript(2) lsReq(3) lsUpdate(4) lsAck(5)

ospfLsdbType %parm[#6]%; routerLink(1) networkLink(2) summaryLink(3) asSummaryLink(4) asExternalLink(5) multicastLink(6) nssaExternalLink(7)

ospfLsdbLsid %parm[#7]%;

ospfLsdbRouterId %parm[#8]%;
event.logmsg: ospfTxRetransmit trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfNbrRtrId=%parm[#4]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#5]% ospfLsdbType=%parm[#6]% ospfLsdbLsid=%parm[#7]% ospfLsdbRouterId=%parm[#8]%

event.descr:
An ospfOriginateLsa trap signifies that a new LSA has been originated by this router. This trap should not be invoked for simple refreshes of LSAs (which happesn every 30 minutes), but instead will only be invoked when an LSA is (re)originated due to a topology change. Addi- tionally, this trap does not include LSAs that are being flushed because they have reached MaxAge.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfLsdbAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfLsdbType %parm[#3]%; routerLink(1) networkLink(2) summaryLink(3) asSummaryLink(4) asExternalLink(5) multicastLink(6) nssaExternalLink(7)

ospfLsdbLsid %parm[#4]%;

ospfLsdbRouterId %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfOriginateLsa trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfLsdbAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfLsdbType=%parm[#3]% ospfLsdbLsid=%parm[#4]% ospfLsdbRouterId=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfNbrStateChange trap signifies that there has been a change in the state of a non- virtual OSPF neighbor. This trap should be generated when the neighbor state regresses (e.g., goes from Attempt or Full to 1-Way or Down) or progresses to a terminal state (e.g., 2-Way or Full). When an neighbor transitions from or to Full on non-broadcast multi-access and broadcast networks, the trap should be gen- erated by the designated router. A designated router transitioning to Down will be noted by ospfIfStateChange.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfNbrIpAddr %parm[#2]%;

ospfNbrAddressLessIndex %parm[#3]%;

ospfNbrRtrId %parm[#4]%;

ospfNbrState %parm[#5]%; down(1) attempt(2) init(3) twoWay(4) exchangeStart(5) exchange(6) loading(7) full(8)
event.logmsg: ospfNbrStateChange trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfNbrIpAddr=%parm[#2]% ospfNbrAddressLessIndex=%parm[#3]% ospfNbrRtrId=%parm[#4]% ospfNbrState=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfAuthFailure trap signifies that a packet has been received on a non-virtual in- terface from a router whose authentication key or authentication type conflicts with this router's authentication key or authentication type.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfPacketSrc %parm[#4]%;

ospfConfigErrorType %parm[#5]%; badVersion(1) areaMismatch(2) unknownNbmaNbr(3) unknownVirtualNbr(4) authTypeMismatch(5) authFailure(6) netMaskMismatch(7) helloIntervalMismatch(8) deadIntervalMismatch(9) optionMismatch(10)

ospfPacketType %parm[#6]%; hello(1) dbDescript(2) lsReq(3) lsUpdate(4) lsAck(5)
event.logmsg: ospfIfAuthFailure trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfPacketSrc=%parm[#4]% ospfConfigErrorType=%parm[#5]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#6]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfStateChange trap signifies that there has been a change in the state of a non-virtual OSPF interface. This trap should be generated when the interface state regresses (e.g., goes from Dr to Down) or progresses to a terminal state (i.e., Point-to-Point, DR Other, Dr, or Backup).

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfIfState %parm[#4]%; down(1) loopback(2) waiting(3) pointToPoint(4) designatedRouter(5) backupDesignatedRouter(6) otherDesignatedRouter(7)
event.logmsg: ospfIfStateChange trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfIfState=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An ospfMaxAgeLsa trap signifies that one of the LSA in the router's link-state database has aged to MaxAge.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfLsdbAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfLsdbType %parm[#3]%; routerLink(1) networkLink(2) summaryLink(3) asSummaryLink(4) asExternalLink(5) multicastLink(6) nssaExternalLink(7)

ospfLsdbLsid %parm[#4]%;

ospfLsdbRouterId %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfMaxAgeLsa trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfLsdbAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfLsdbType=%parm[#3]% ospfLsdbLsid=%parm[#4]% ospfLsdbRouterId=%parm[#5]%
